There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of e=centered peace.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My stuatrion at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I o

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessently told me to go out and play with my (

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessently told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends.

There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new c

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in ve

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.

I began to bhave a fahat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a faihat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dre

From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a singkle member of my family came to watch me get my diplom

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Briother Mari

From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Briother Marian was there, and came

Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But w

Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Throu

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decaude, I hav

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decaude, I have tried to find him, but there is no real t

I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decaude, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think

I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkisons. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his dishevel brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle. and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (virtually nonexistent) friends. I was a lonely, angry, confused and very depressed teenager.

Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

But not in my heart.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkinson's. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his disheveled brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted, understood, noticed and liked by him. He was smart, kind, gentle and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher, but he was also a good man.

My situation at the time I took his class was bad. On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

But not in my heart.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkinson's. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his disheveled brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted. He was smart, kind, gentle, and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher and a good man.

My situation at the time was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (nonexistent) friends. I was lonely, angry,confused and very depressed teenager.
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

But not in my heart.

He was smart, kind, gentle, and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher and a good man.

My situation at the time was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (nonexistent) friends. I was lonely, angry confused and hopelesly sad
Brother Marian was the first person I ever met who seemed to understand me., who seemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. That something was hope.
I began to bhave a fainh hope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never was to see him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

But not in my heart.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkinson's. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his disheveled brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted. He was smart, kind, gentle, and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher and a good man.

My situation at the time was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (nonexistent) friends. I was lonely, confused and hopelessly sad.
Brother Marian wseemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. 

That something was hope.  began to bhope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never sa him again. Through the decade, I have tried to find him, but there is no real trail and I think he has died.

But not in my heart.

I went to a Roman Catholic high school. I was not that religious, so my attitude toward the teaching Brothers was less than optimal. I was smart as well as a smart ass.

But then I met Brother Marian. He was a slight man, and walked crookedly as if he had been a polio victim or had Parkinson's. There was always a few flakes of dandruff on his black suitcoat under his disheveled brown/blonde hair. He taught English Literature. From the first day of class, I felt accepted. He was smart, kind, gentle, and full of centered peace. He was a good teacher and a good man.

My situation at the time was bad. Alcoholism, mental illness and poverty had wracked my family and I often spent hours aimlessly riding my boke through the surrounding neighborhoods because my mother incessantly told me to go out and play with my (nonexistent) friends. I was lonely, confused and hopelessly sad.
Brother Marian wseemed to care about me. Something new developed within me during Brother Marian's class, something valuable and hitherto in very short supply. 

That something was hope.  began to bhope tat I could be a good person, that I could be happy, that I could have a good life.
 That was a game-changer.
I began to read books.
 I began to dream.

On graduation day, not a single member of my family came to watch me get my diploma. But Brother Marian was there, and came looking for me after the ceremony. He was the only person who cared enough to come and find me.

But we missed each other and I never saw him again. Through the intervening decades, I have tried to find him, but there is no trailI think he has died.

But not in my heart.
